How to work with teams that turn to AI instead of UX

“For example, our team was working with a PM creating sketches in Miro. After a meeting, the PM took the work, stuck it in Google Stitch, and created a pretty wireframe that looked nice at first glance.”

I’ve been interviewing 15 global design leaders about design, metrics, and AI, and one pattern keeps emerging: design teams are struggling to stay in the loop when AI tools enter the workflow.

Fortunately, the Design Director said, “When you looked a little bit closer, beyond what it looked like, you realized it wasn’t quite right. It was broken in many places, but it made our team think.”

However, despite what you might think, these experiences of cutting UX out aren’t new.

If you find yourself in this situation, here’s what to do.

The Reality: Designers Will Never Have Enough Time

Many designers realize, especially if you are a small UX team that there’s always a cap on how much time you can take.

If you take 6 months to conduct deep research and barely generate any sketches during that time?
